title: Beyond and back: Andalusia, Spain Big Ride
content:
Cyclist
Beyond and back: Andalusia, Spain Big Ride

You might not think it to gaze up into these vast mountains, but thanks to a network of tracks it’s possible to circumnavigate the Sierra Nevada mountain range, winding far above the sprawling white towns at its feet and deep into its wilds.

Inspired by an old hiking trail, in 2011 Andalucía Tourism and the International Mountain Bike Association stitched together eight otherwise disparate segments to create the Transnevada. At almost 500km long, this set of gravel tracks encircles the range’s rocky peaks like a jagged halo.

Related Posts

Best places to cycle in the French Pyrenees

Cyclist magazine issue 147: on sale now!

Big Ride: Into thin air on the Pico del Veleta

The route sits around 2,000m above sea level at all points, but because it traverses the Sierra Nevada’s slopes rather than climbs them more directly, the path mostly rises and falls within a fairly narrow bandwidth, which makes riding the Transnevada surprisingly manageable… once you get up there, of course.

Gorging on sunshine

Nestled in one of the Alpujarra region’s innumerable gorges, morning sees the town of Cádiar cloaked in shadow while the surrounding peaks get first dibs on the rising sun, their yellow brightness at odds with the blue light down in town. Even in late autumn, conditions here are sufficient to heat up the coast, some 40km to the south, to temperatures the British summer would be proud of. However, given that the average altitude of civilisation here is around 1,200m, dawns are fresh enough to wake you up like a strong coffee.

Cádiar is a town typical of the area, its old, whitewashed dwellings squashed haphazardly together, with steep, narrow streets twisting in between. Its sleepy atmosphere belies a tumultuous history that runs in parallel to other villages in the region.

Thanks to the extreme terrain, Alpujarra has always been somewhat cut off from the rest of Spain, and as such it developed its own distinct culture, prospering during the Arab-Andalusian period thanks to its specialist silk production. But by the 1400s, religious wars between the Moors and invading Catholics had caused immeasurable suffering and the population never really recovered, a fact that helps explain why the area continues to fly under the radar in the 21st century.

The second of two civil wars here was rumoured to have started when a rich landowner proclaimed himself king in or around Cádiar itself, with the town acting as his base of operations. But these days, all such notions of brutal accessions are long forgotten, and Cádiar is operations base only to Vamos Cycling, a cycling holiday company led by Gary and Sarah Williams.

It turns out that the town is equally advantageously placed for riders in search of a challenge as it is for rebel war leaders in search of a defensible HQ.

The only way is up

As we pick our way out of the still-silent town, the scale of today’s challenge is highlighted when I notice Gary’s gearing setup. His tiny mountain bike chainring has more in common with the sprockets in the middle of my cassette than it does with the 44t plate driving my chain, which I now realise is grossly oversized. I rapidly command my rear derailleur to shunt my chain to the top of the cassette, where I have an ominous feeling it will need to stay. With a mixture of pity and humour, Gary quips that at least I won’t need to worry about shifting all that much today.

Before the wars and politics of the Middle Ages affected Alpujarra, the Moors cultivated a variety of produce on its rocky slopes, including olives and citrus fruits. Ingeniously, water came from snowmelt much higher up among the Sierra Nevada’s peaks, channelled down to the terraces and pastures in specially dug irrigation canals, many of which are still evident, much to the benefit of local vintners. Today, these terraces produce renowned Tempranillo from some of the highest-altitude vineyards in Europe.

The canals, on the other hand, scythe vertically downhill, thereby tending to govern the direction of any road that isn’t tarmac, which is why the first portion of our ride sees more than 5km rise at around 10%.

Cádiar shrinks below us as we climb towards bigger peaks, eventually picking up the southernmost stretch of the Transnevada trail. We’ll only be sampling around 40km of it today, but with the extra distance required to get up, down and back again, even that small chunk should require spending most of the day in the saddle.

For the first time in a while, the gravel eases in gradient as we swing onto the Transnevada proper and start heading east. That’s east in the vaguest sense, for the route tracks the contours of the mountains’ barrancos – fronds of rock that radiate outwards from the truly massive peaks at the centre.

Consequently, we end up zigging north and zagging south more than heading directly east, each new barranco bringing with it fresh views at a surprising rate. From their western side we look out over ripples of land that steadily peter out into the sea, glistening invitingly despite looking impossibly distant.

On the rocky tendrils’ eastern sides we pedal further into the Sierra Nevada, where the sky is pierced by vast, snow-capped mountaintops. Mulhacén, mainland Spain’s highest mountain, is ensconced in there, as is the Pico de Veleta, home to Europe’s highest paved road at 3,398m.

There’s no tarmac under our tyre treads today, though. Instead, there’s the wholesome crunch of gravel, but the surface is far from uniform. The Sierra Nevada’s altitude creates microclimates that correspondingly affect the conditions below. For us that means sometimes the surface is dry and dusty, at other times rocky and loose, at other times still claggy and wet.

But while there’s the occasional technical section (and I’m told there are some truly gnarly parts of the Transnevada elsewhere), the going is generally steady in gradient and relatively simple technically. This allows me to focus on finding a rhythm and riding efficiently; it’s important not to dig too deep, too often at this altitude.

Off-road climbs in the Pyrenees and Alps can often be so rocky and steep that it becomes as much about the line you take as your physical fitness, hence going into the red is sometimes unavoidable. Here, though, the gravel is closer in character to the road, so it pays to employ the same steady tempo as road riding.

Remote ecology

The sun is high in the sky, but with it being autumn we’ve swerved the blistering heat of summer that would otherwise make the relentless draggy climbs and shallow descents interminable. However, we do have to contend with the effects of recent rainstorms, which have carved deep gulleys into some silt-like sections and exposed the same slabs of rock that make up the slopes around us.

That isn’t to say this area is arid though. While some of the snowmelt is artificially siphoned off to fuel the agricultural terraces below, most of it naturally saturates the altitude band the Transnevada runs through. As such, myriad tough grasses and bushes cover the scree, and frequent stretches of the trail weave through pine forests. In the spring, wildflowers carpet the slopes.

There’s incredible biodiversity here, which is at odds with, but also because of, the almost complete lack of human activity. With every pedal stroke the sense of isolation, of being lost in the monumental acreage of the mountains, becomes more acute. At the start of the day we saw a couple of hardy farm trucks and a lone fellow cyclist; by this point, it has been hours since we’ve seen anyone at all.

With no other distractions, the rhythmic up and down, in and out of the trail is almost meditative in its tranquillity, but there’s an underlying feeling of vulnerability out here too. It takes some reassurance from the ever-buoyant Gary that, despite appearances, there are frequent potential escape tracks that hang off the Transnevada trail like rug tassels, leading down to Alpujarran towns much like Cádiar. Still, the magnitude of the scenery makes this a cycling destination like no other.

It’s a fact illustrated by the weather, as the swirling winds manage to hold an otherwise diminutive cloud directly over the sun. The temperature plummets, and riding gear that has so far been comfortable suddenly feels totally inadequate. We don jackets, a reminder that Mother Nature is pretty fickle and those who decide to venture here would do well to come prepared.

Over the edge

All too soon our time on the Transnevada comes to an end – if we’re to make it home before dark, we must turn off the Sierra Nevada’s gravel lasso and make our way back via more conventional routes. As I learned this morning, the gravel trails that connect the Transnevada to civilisation below do so rather directly, so our exit quite literally means tipping off the edge of a mountain.

Within mere metres we’re going faster than we have done all day, following a rocky track that tumbles like a waterfall down to the town of Válor. The thrill of speed is tempered by the wariness of chaos all around: rocks ping off the underside of my down tube, handlebars buck in my hands and branches appear from nowhere, the vegetation either side as unkempt as the narrow trail surface.

It’s certainly one of the spicier descents I’ve done, with a dangerous sense of exposure that isn’t found on the road. Up here there’s nothing to stop you disappearing off the edge if you overcook a bend.

As abruptly as switching on a light in a dark room, everything becomes serene. The cracking, crunching and pinging stop. The bone-shaking vibrations that have turned my vision blurry cease. After hours on broken surfaces we touch tarmac for the first time today.

We’ve turned onto the A-4130, a road that strafes a large portion of the Sierra Nevada’s southern edge. It’s more substantial than the Transnevada but it too is at the whim of the mountains, so we begin broadly tracking the trail, just in the opposite direction and around 1,000m lower down.

We relish the return to smooth road, and it strikes me that the approach to gravel over here is notably different to how we ride it in Britain. Back home it’s about piecing together tracks and trails with the minimum amount of road linking them; here the gravel is so expansive and challenging that any opportunity to ride on the road is welcome respite.

The result is that our return to the tarmac has us feeling like we’re floating and the final kilometres tick easily by. While we’re no longer as high up, the views to our left of the dramatically plunging foothills – mountains themselves were they not situated next to the Sierra Nevada range – are just as good for being that much closer.

These hills don’t control the meteorological conditions to the same extent, though, so the storm clouds the mountains have kept at bay all day now finally close over us. Distant rumbles of thunder can be heard. The contrast between the purple rainclouds and the orange late-afternoon sun is beautifully dramatic.

Finally Cádiar shifts back into view, and we race the rain towards it. We lose the contest a few kilometres from home and the roads become slick, so we take a ribbed concrete offshoot that serves as a back way into Narila, the next village along. At negative 25%, it’s the most extreme gradient of the day, but by now I’m not surprised it exists as the main route into town. Taking on gradients like this, whether up or down, is simply a fact of life for any cyclists in Alpujarra.

Cádiar rises up to our left, meaning there’s one last short, sharp climb to tick off before we can call our day done. In other circumstances I’d have baulked at the task, but finishing the day just as I started it – with my chain glued to the biggest sprocket and my legs burning – feels like a fitting end.

Hidden gems

Fancy a return to tarmac? The Sierra Nevada has plenty of stunning climbs

Pico de Veleta

Distance: 43km Elevation: 2,700m

This monster starts outside of Granada and grinds up one of the biggest mountains in the range. The gradient is never particularly difficult: the climb’s length and the altitude are the rider’s real enemies.

• Classic Climbs: Pico de Veleta

Trevélez

Distance: 34km Elevation: 1,007m

Starting in Órgiva to the west of Cádiar, this climb heads northeast to Trevélez, making for a quick spin home. At 1,486m it’s one of the highest villages in Spain, but the climb is easy to ride fast, with frequent flat and downhill sections.

Cáñar

Distance: 8.3km Elevation: 566m

Another start in Órgiva, but this climb to Cáñar is shorter and sharper, with plenty of 15% sections. The road surface is flawless though, and the tightly coiled switchbacks are reminiscent of Italy’s Stelvio Pass.

How we did it

Travel

Malaga is the best airport to fly into for easy access to most of the Alpujarra region, and Cyclist flew with Easyjet from London Gatwick. In October, flights shouldn’t cost more than £150, but you’ll need to factor in the expense of travelling with a bike, which is an extra £45 each way. From there it’s around a two-hour drive east to Cádiar.

Accommodation

We stayed at Vamos Cycling’s HQ, Gary and Sarah Williams’ townhouse in the centre of Cádiar. The spacious, well-appointed house sleeps eight comfortably and most rooms have views out over the town square and the mountains beyond. There’s a fully equipped workshop on the ground floor that makes unpacking bikes easy, and as a bike mechanic in his spare time, Gary is on hand to help. A fully catered, fully supported week of gravel riding costs £750. For more information visit vamoscycling.com.

Thanks

We must extend a huge thank you to Gary and Sarah for hosting us during what would have otherwise been a rare bit of downtime for them both. Sarah kept us well fed with a wide array of delicious, locally sourced food and drink, and Gary was a consummate ride guide, supplying local knowledge throughout the route and only scoffing a little when we turned up hopelessly over-geared.

author: mdonlevy
